head.title: Earnings at Coke Bottler Narrowly Beat Expectations

hedline.hl1: Earnings at Coke Bottler Narrowly Beat Expectations

abstract.p: Coca-Cola Enterprises says second-quarter profit rose 26 percent, narrowly beating analysts' expectations; profit increased to $131 million compared with $104 million in year-earlier quarter; revenue rose 8 percent, to $4.03 billion from $3.8 billion (M)

block.p: In results that narrowly beat analysts' expectations, Coca-Cola Enterprises said yesterday that its second-quarter profit rose 26 percent.
Profit from operations at the company, Coca-Cola's largest bottler, increased to $131 million, or 31 cents a share, compared with $104 million, or 24 cents a share, in the quarter a year earlier.
In results that narrowly beat analysts' expectations, Coca-Cola Enterprises said yesterday that its second-quarter profit rose 26 percent.
Profit from operations at the company, Coca-Cola's largest bottler, increased to $131 million, or 31 cents a share, compared with $104 million, or 24 cents a share, in the quarter a year earlier.

In the most recent period, a one-time charge of $12 million for layoffs in Britain, where Coca-Cola Enterprises is struggling with lower-priced Coke products in what has been one of its more lucrative businesses, made net income $123 million, or 29 cents a share. Results in the period a year earlier included a $103 million charge for recalling products from France and Belgium, making net income $34 million, or 8 cents a share.
Analysts had expected the company to earn 28 cents a share, according to First Call/Thomson Financial.
Revenue rose 8 percent, to $4.03 billion from $3.8 billion, though sales volume declined in North America, its largest market, and in Britain, another major market.

''They were slightly ahead because of higher pricing in North America and higher sales costs, but it was nothing to write home about,'' said Bill Pecoriello, a beverage analyst for Sanford C. Bernstein.

Volume in North America, which accounts for most of the bottler's sales, continues to be uncertain. While revenue per case increased 5 percent, consumers seemed to be balking at higher prices charged in supermarkets, where until recently Coke and Pepsi were locked in a price war that kept the cost of six-packs and two-liter bottles low.

Coke and its archrival are betting that higher prices will eventually be accepted by consumers, but so far consumers seem reluctant. Sales of store-brand soda, which is cheaper, have increased at double-digit rates this year, according to data compiled by Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette. The soft-drink category is up 2.5 percent for the year, while store-brand soda has grown 9.5 percent.

Volume growth is essential to Coca-Cola's earnings growth. The company's chairman has said he expects volume to increase 5 percent to 6 percent worldwide this year, and rise 7 percent to 8 percent next year.

''We continue to expect full-year volume in North America to be flat to up 1 percent versus the prior year,'' said John R. Alm, Coca-Cola Enterprises' president and chief operating officer. Coca-Cola Enterprises, which is 40 percent owned by Coca-Cola, accounts for 74 percent of Coke's North American sales in bottles and cans.

In a conference call with analysts in May, Mr. Alm warned that domestic volume would increase just 1 percent to 2 percent this year, while estimates had been 2 percent to 3 percent. After he made that announcement, his company's share price plummeted $6.9375, to $15.625, a 52-week low. Shares of Coca-Cola were dragged lower as well, losing $3, to $48.9375.

The newly lowered volume estimates did not take a toll on the stock yesterday. Shares of Coca-Cola Enterprises rose yesterday by just less than $1, to close at $18.4375. Coca-Cola is holding a conference call today to discuss its own second-quarter results, which are being announced this morning.

The bottler's sales were up 5 percent in the more lucrative vending area, the company said. In Europe, sales rose 15.5 percent in the quarter, although the second quarter of last year was a particularly bleak one, in which Coke products were pulled from store shelves and production halted in Belgium and France because of contamination fears.
